p: Similarly, by 2012, more directors had become more certain that over the next 20Â years, their jurisdiction would experience one or more serious public health problems as a result of climate change (an increase of 17.8%), while more directors also became more certain their jurisdiction would not (an increase of 9.3%). Two state-based surveys of health department directors showed divergent profiles: in 2008, nearly all directors in California (94%) perceived climate change to be a threat to public health [ 12], whereas in 2009, only a minority of directors in New York State (32%) perceived climate change to be occurring yet in their jurisdiction [ 13].
